title: MATH 012: R-Labs
text:
What is R?
R is a versatile computer program that enables a wide range of statistical calculations and data analysis. Developed and maintained largely through voluntary contributions from statisticians globally, R is a free and open-source tool available on most operating systems, including Windows, Mac OS, and Linux.
Beyond statistical analysis, R also excels in creating graphics and functions as a full-fledged programming language. In this series of labs, we will only begin to explore the extensive capabilities that R offers.

title: MATH 012: R-Labs
text:
How can we run R?
The base R environment is always accessible, but most users prefer to work with an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for a more user-friendly interface. RStudio, for example, is one of the most popular IDEs today.





Although you can download and run R locally on your system, it’s not necessary for our labs, as they can be completed directly within self-contained webpages. We recommend sticking to the content provided on the lab webpages to familiarize yourself with the syntax. Once you feel comfortable with the language, you can easily run R on your laptop.

title: MATH 012: R-Labs
text:
R-Lab procedure during recitations
In most recitation sessions, we will dedicate about 20 minutes to a lab focused on R programming and data analysis.

Each lab includes a brief tutorial that you can easily follow.
At the end of each lab, you’ll find a few questions that you can answer based on the lab materials.
Finally, complete the Gradescope lab quiz, which is directly based on the lab questions.

While lab topics are often closely related to class content, they may diverge, especially around the middle of the semester. Feel free to discuss the questions with fellow students, and don’t hesitate to ask the TA for help!

title: Lab 2
text:
While defining variables (objects), the significance of variable naming in programming is immense. Selecting clear and descriptive names for variables is vital for several reasons:

Readability and Understandability: Clear and descriptive variable names enhance the readability and comprehension of your code.
Maintainability and Debugging: Thoughtfully named variables simplify code maintenance and debugging processes.
Collaboration: In a team setting, consistent and clear variable naming conventions are crucial for effective collaboration.
Self-Documentation: Meaningful variable names serve as self-documentation, making the code more intuitive.
Code Reusability: Adopting good variable naming practices supports greater code reusability.

Sometimes, clear naming requires using multiple words in a variable name, but spaces are not allowed. A common approach is to separate words with underscores, as demonstrated previously, such as \(\texttt{morning\_temperature\_august}\).


Let us assign relevant names to the following variables:



#
Feature
Value




1
Body temperature in Fahrenheit
98


2
Number of shoes for Sam
11


3
Weight of a elephant in pounds
12,050




Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.




A vector is a sequence of finite elements and serves as the basic object in R. For example, a single number like “3” is considered a vector of length 1. To create a vector, we use the \(\texttt{c()}\) function, where the name is an abbreviation of “combine.”

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
As learned, we can assign a descriptive variable name to the vector:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
One of the powerful features of vectors in R is the ability to perform the same calculation on every element with a single command, i.e., element-wise operation. For example, when converting weights from pounds to kilograms, we can multiply 0.454. This operation can be applied to all the numbers in a vector simultaneously:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
To access a specific number in a vector, you add square brackets after the vector name and place the index of the desired element inside the brackets. The “index” refers to the position of the item within the vector, with the first element having an index of 1, and so on. For example, the third element of the vector \(\texttt{weight\_kg}\) is:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.



As we discussed in class, we can use the “mean” and “median” to measure the central tendency of our data, with the mode also being an option in some cases. In R, the functions \(\texttt{mean()}\) and \(\texttt{median()}\) can be used to obtain the mean and median of a vector, respectively.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.



We can also easily calculate the summation and length of a vector by using the functions, \(\texttt{sum()}\) and \(\texttt{length()}\).

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Compute the mean of \(\texttt{weight\_kg}\) by using \(\texttt{sum()}\) and \(\texttt{length()}\) functions. (Do not use \(\texttt{mean()}\) function.)

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.





BMI is a measurement of a person’s leanness or corpulence based on their height and weight, and is intended to quantify tissue mass. It is widely used as a general indicator of whether a person has a healthy body weight for their height and it is defined by: \[\textbf{BMI}=703\times \frac{\text{weight (lb)}}{ \text{(height (in)})^2}\] Suppose the variable \(\texttt{weight\_pound}\) is the weights of seven Lehigh students. Also, the corresponding height observations in inches are \[70,\;72,\;72.5,\;66,\;74,\;66.5,\;72.\]



Save the height observations in a variable by using a descriptive name. (Uncomment and use the data.)
Calculate the BMIs of the seven students.
Compute the mean and median of the BMIs .


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

People often underreport how frequently they engage in antisocial behaviors like peeing in swimming pools. Urine, beyond being unpleasant, reacts with chlorine to produce toxic chemicals like trichloramine, a common cause of skin irritation for swimmers. Researchers found that the artificial sweetener ACE, which passes through the body unmetabolized and in consistent amounts, can be used to measure the amount of urine in a pool by analyzing ACE concentrations. Below is a list of ACE concentrations (measured in ng/L) from 15 different pools in the US: \[ 438,  211,  640,   85,   83,  350,  138,   49,  465,  489,55, 1086,   71, 1058,  247.\]



In R, create a vector of these data and give it an appropriate name. (Uncomment and use the data.)
What is the mean ACE concentration in these 15 pools?
Since urine contains an average ACE of 4000 ng/ml, we can obtain the urin concentration (ml/L) by dividing each value by 4000 from the ACE concentration data. Compute the urin concentration and it a suitable name.
What is the mean urine concentration (in ml) per liter?
Use R to calculate the average amount of urine (in ml) in a 500,000 L pool.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 1
text:
You can type commands in the “Console”.
Type “2+2” and then hit “Shift+Return” or click the “Run Code” icon. You’ll see that R can perform simple calculations, just like a calculator. The result, 4, will appear, with a “[1]” label indicating that this is the first element of the output. While this labeling may seem unnecessary for simple answers, it becomes quite helpful for more complex outputs.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.



In your code scripts, it’s often useful to include text that isn’t evaluated by R. This allows you to leave notes for yourself or a friend about what the next line of code does, its strengths and limitations, or any other information you want to remember. To add a comment, start the line with the hash symbol “#”. R will ignore everything on that line after the “#”.


Let us try the rest of the fundamental arithmetic operations:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.




You can use a variety of mathematical functions for calculations. For example, log() calculates the natural logarithm of a number.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Parentheses serve two purposes in R: they group elements within calculations and denote the arguments passed to functions. The “arguments” of a function refer to the values provided as input. For example, in “log(3)”, the “log()” function is applied to the argument “3”.
Similarly, we can also use “exp()” for the exponential function.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Another useful mathematical function is “sqrt()”, which calculates the square root of a number. For example, “sqrt(4)” returns:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
To calculate a value with an exponent, used the “^” symbol. For example \(4^3\) is written as:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Let us compute the following mathematical expression: \[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi} 0.5}\log\left(\frac{(12-10.8)^2}{0.4}\right).\]

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.




In R, we can store information by assigning it to objects. For example, to create an object named “x” with a value of “24”, you can write:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
The part in the middle—a less-than sign followed by a hyphen, resembling a left-facing arrow—indicates to R that the value on the right should be assigned to the object on the left. After executing the command, whenever we use “x”, it will be replaced by its value, “24”. For instance, if we add “12” to “x”, we should expect a result of “36”.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
You can reassign a new value to a object. E.g.,

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.




Calculate the following math expressions.



\((23\times 6)+3\).
\(13^3-1100\).
\(\log(23)\) with the natural log.
\(\sqrt{81}/(3^3)\).


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Please complete the following semester start survey. Participation is voluntary, and you may choose to skip any questions: Give Us Your Input

title: Lab 3
text:
A data frame in R stores a data set where columns represent variables and rows correspond to individuals. Each element in the data frame is an observation or measurement of a variable for a specific individual. (It’s similar to an Excel sheet.)
A data frame is typically assigned a name, which is used to indicate to R’s functions which data set to work with. For example, a built-in data set “mtcars” contains car specification information in 1970’s. This data frame has 11 variables and 32 individual cars. The following \(\texttt{head()}\) function shows the variables names and first six observations. Also, use \(\texttt{help(mtcars)}\) for the variable descriptions.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 3
text:
A data frame in R stores a data set where columns represent variables and rows correspond to individuals. Each element in the data frame is an observation or measurement of a variable for a specific individual. (It’s similar to an Excel sheet.)
A data frame is typically assigned a name, which is used to indicate to R’s functions which data set to work with. For example, a built-in data set “mtcars” contains car specification information in 1970’s. This data frame has 11 variables and 32 individual cars. The following \(\texttt{head()}\) function shows the variables names and first six observations. Also, use \(\texttt{help(mtcars)}\) for the variable descriptions.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 3
text:
Subsetting Data
Sometimes, we are interested in a particular variables in a data set. Then, it becomes necessary to extract one of the variables (columns) from the a data frame for further analysis.
When your data frame has variable names, then this can be easily done by \(\texttt{\$}\) command. For example, use \(\texttt{mtcars\$hp}\) to extract \(\texttt{horse power}\) variable.

title: Lab 3
text:
Subsetting Data Frame
Sometimes, we are interested in extracting one of the variables (columns) from the a data frame for further analysis.
When your data frame has variable names, then this can be easily done by \(\texttt{\$}\) command. For example, use \(\texttt{mtcars\$hp}\) to extract \(\texttt{horsepower}\) variable.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Another way to extract a variable is to use an index with \(\texttt{[]}\). Recall that we cal select a specific element in a vector using its index, e.g., \(\texttt{HP[2]}\) returns the second element of the \(\texttt{HP}\). Similarly, we can use \(\texttt{mtcars[,4]}\) to extract the variable in the fourth column, \(\texttt{horsepower}\).

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Note that the first argument is empty because it is used to select a specific row (an individual car). By leaving it empty, we are selecting all rows (cars) of the \(\texttt{horsepower}\) variable. Similarly, we can extract the value of a particular variable for a specific car, e.g. \(\texttt{mtcars[3,4]}\) retrieves the horsepower of “Datsun 710”.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Lastly, we can simultaneously select or deselect multiple variables and/or observations by combining \(\texttt{[]}\), \(\texttt{c()}\) and \(\texttt{-}\).

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
I believe you can now recognize the patterns. Mastering data subsetting is a crucial skill in data analysis, and we have just covered the fundamental procedures.

Example
Consider the \(\texttt{mtcars}\) data again.

Extract the weight variable using \(\texttt{\$}\) command.
Extract the Miles/gallon of Honda Civic using \(\texttt{[]}\) command.
You can check the car names with the \(\texttt{rownames(mtcars)}\) command.
Extract the \(\texttt{mpg}\) and \(\texttt{hp}\) variables using \(\texttt{[]}\) command.
Extract the \(\texttt{mpg}\) and \(\texttt{hp}\) variables except for the \(\texttt{Merc}\) cars.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 3
text:
Measure of Variation
We covered several measures of variation, including “variance”, “standard deviation”, “range”, and “interquartile Range (IQR)”. While calculating these by hand can be tedious, R offers quick and easy outputs using the functions \(\texttt{var()}\), \(\texttt{sd()}\), \(\texttt{range()}\), and \(\texttt{IQR()}\).

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 3
text:
Lab Questions

The famous “iris” data set gives the measurements in centimeters of the variables sepal length and width and petal length and width, respectively, for 50 flowers from each of 3 species of iris.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Extract the \(\texttt{Sepal.Length}\) and \(\texttt{Petal.Length}\) variables using the \(\texttt{\$}\) command, and save those in \(\texttt{SL}\) and \(\texttt{PL}\), respectively.
Compare the variances of \(\texttt{SL}\) and \(\texttt{PL}\). Which variable exhibits greater variation in terms of variance?
Extract the \(\texttt{Sepal.Width}\) and \(\texttt{Petal.Width}\) variables using the \(\texttt{[]}\) command, and save those in \(\texttt{SW}\) and \(\texttt{PW}\), respectively.
Compare the IQRs of \(\texttt{SW}\) and \(\texttt{PW}\). Which variable exhibits greater variation in terms of IQR?


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Let us recall the fomulas for the sample variance.


The sample variance can be computed from the following formula: \[s^2=\frac{1}{n-1}\sum_{i=1}^n\left(x_i-\bar{x}\right)^2,\] where \(x\) is a numerical variable of length \(n\). Calculate the variance of \(\texttt{SL}\) without using \(\texttt{var()}\) function. (You could use \(\texttt{mean()}\), \(\texttt{sum()}\), and \(\texttt{length()}\) functions.) Verify that your result matches the value provided in 1-ii.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Additionally, we have learned an alternative formula for variance calculation (also known as the ‘computing formula’): \[s^2=\frac{1}{n-1}\left\{\sum_{i=1}^nx_i^2-\bar{x}^2\right\}.\] Similar to the previous case, calculate the variance of \(\texttt{PL}\) using this formula, based on the \(\texttt{mean()}\), \(\texttt{sum()}\), and \(\texttt{length()}\) functions. Verify that your result matches the value provided in 1-ii.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 4
text:
Basic Graphics in R
R offers a variety of options for creating visual displays in statistics. While base R itself provides sufficient quality for many plots, additional packages like \(\texttt{ggplot2}\) or \(\texttt{lattice}\) to produce “publishable” quality graphics. In our lab sessions, we will focus on the basic R graphics.

title: Lab 4
text:
Frequency Tables
As we discussed in class, a frequency table summarizes the information from the corresponding data set. It also serves as an important intermediate step for creating visual displays such as pie charts, bar plots, histograms, and more.
Let us create a frequency table of a categorical variable \(\texttt{Hand}\) using the function \(\texttt{table()}\).

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
We can also create a 2-by-2 (relative) frequency table (or contingency table) with two categorical variables.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Now, we can finally created conditional frequency table.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Based on the results of conditional frequency table, we can answer questions such as: Which gender prefers MLB? Which gender prefers NBA?

title: Lab 4
text:
Beginning Semester Survey Data
For illustrations, we will use our beginning semester survey data. It contains 136 observations and 16 variables as follows:

01. Sports:    What is your favorite professional sport? 
02. States:    How many states in the US have you traveled to? 
03. Cat_Dog:   Are you more of a cat person or a dog person? 
04. Pets:      What is the number of pets you and your family currently have? 
05. Gender:    What is your gender? 
06. Browser:   What is your preferred internet browser? 
08. Shoes:     How many pairs of shoes do you have? 
09. Height:    How tall are you (inch)? 
10. MO_Height: What is your mothers height (inch)? 
11. FA_Height: What is your fathers height (inch)? 
12. Arrival:   How many minutes does it take for you to reach the recitation classroom from your residence? 
13. Sleep:     How many HOURS did you sleep last night, to the nearest half-hour? 
14. Number:    What is your favorite whole number between 1 and 10? 
15. Hand:      Are you right- or left-handed? 
16. Credit:    How many credits are you taking this semester? 

Let us check the variable name and the first six observations by using the function \(\texttt{head()}\):

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 4
text:
Bar plots
Bar plot is a very useful for any categorical variables, regardless the # of categories. To create a bar plot, we can use the function \(\texttt{barplot()}\). Note that the function accepts a \(\texttt{table}\) object that we created above.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 4
text:
Bar Plot
A bar plot is highly useful for displaying categorical data, regardless of the number of categories. To create a bar plot, we can use the \(\texttt{barplot()}\) function. Note that the function accepts the \(\texttt{table}\) object that we created earlier.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
For any plotting functions, the \(\texttt{main}\) argument can be used to add a “title” to the plot.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Example
Select a single categorical variable from the data set, and create a bar plot with an appropriate title. (We will address bivariate categorical variables in a lab question.)

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 4
text:
Histogram
Histogram is a versatile graphical display for a single numerical variable (data). It directly accepts a numerical vector as its first argument. Let us create a histogram for the \(\texttt{Height}\) variable.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
The histogram reveals that the distribution of the \(\texttt{Height}\) variable is right-skewed.

Example
Select a single numerical variable from the data set, and create a histogram with an appropriate title. What is the shape of the distribution?

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 4
text:
Box Plot
Although the histogram is typically our go-to choice for a single numerical variable, there are situations where a box plot is preferable. For instance, if we want to display \(\texttt{Height}\) by \(\texttt{Gender}\), a box plot would be more appropriate.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
This graphical representation makes it easy to compare the differences in \(\texttt{Height}\) between genders. As demonstrated, a box plot is a clear and intuitive choice when we have one numerical variable and one categorical variable.

title: Lab 4
text:
Lab Questions

Let us consider \(\texttt{Browser}\) variable in relation to \(\texttt{Cat\_Dog}\).



Create a frequency table for the \(\texttt{Browser}\) variable.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Create a bar plot using the table object in (i).


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Create a conditional frequency table for \(\texttt{Browser}\) with respect to \(\texttt{Cat\_Dog}\).


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Create a conditional frequency barplot for \(\texttt{Browser}\) with respect to \(\texttt{Cat\_Dog}\). Discuss the percentages of Edge and Safari with respect to the personality.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Let us consider \(\texttt{Shoes}\) variable in relation to \(\texttt{Gender}\). Note that we have one numerical and one categorical variable.



Choose a relevant graphical display to summarize the information of \(\texttt{Shoes}\), and provide the plot.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Choose a relevant graphical display to summarize the information of \(\texttt{Shoes}\) in terms of \(\texttt{Gender}\), and provide the plot.


Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Which gender has a higher central value for \(\texttt{Shoes}\)? Which gender shows greater variability? What can we infer about the number of pairs of shoes with respect to gender?

title: Lab 5
text: Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 5
text:
Analyzing Bivariate Data with R
There are many situations where we are interested in the relationship between two variables. For the discrete bivariate case, a conditional frequency table can be used. For continuous variables, correlation and linear regression analyses are appropriate. In this lab, we focus on the correlation analysis based on a dataset with continuous variables.

title: Lab 5
section: MLB Data: 2023 Regular Season Team Statistics
text:
MLB Data: 2023 Regular Season Team Statistics
With MLB wrapping up its 2024 regular season, let’s use the complete dataset from the 2023 regular season. As depicted in the movie Moneyball (2011), the use of baseball statistics and analytics to measure player and team performance has become widespread. While numerous baseball analytics are used in the field, we will focus on some of the key statistics that measure the offensive and defensive capabilities of MLB teams:

01. Team:  Name of the team 
02. Win_P: Winning Percentage, "# of Wins"/ "Total # of games".
03. RPG:   Runs per Game, the average number of runs a team or player scores in each game. 
04. BA:    Batting Average, "the # of times a batter hits a ball and reaches the base"/"the # of at bats by a batter".   
05. OPS:   On-base plus slugging, the sum of on-base percentage and slugging percentage. 
06. ORPG:  Opponent Runs per Game, the runs per game by the opponent.   
07. ERA:   Earned Run Average, the number of earned runs a pitcher allows per nine innings.    
08. WHIP:  Walks And Hits Per Inning Pitched, the statistic shows how well a pitcher has kept runners off the basepaths, one of his main goals.

In the data set, the variable \(\texttt{Win\_P}\) measures a MLB team’s performance throughout the 2023 season. For offensive capability, we can use the variables \(\texttt{RPG}\), \(\texttt{BA}\), and \(\texttt{OPS}\); whereas, for defensive capability, we can use \(\texttt{ORPG}\), \(\texttt{ERA}\), and \(\texttt{WHIP}\).

title: Lab 5
text:
Offensive Capability
In baseball, offensive capability is closely tied to the performance of batters. We can expect a positive association between offensive measures and winning percentage. This relationship can be quantified using correlation, which provides a unit-less value between -1 and 1. A value close to 1 or -1 indicates a strong positive or negative association, respectively, while a value near 0 indicates no linear association between the variables. In R, the function \(\texttt{cor()}\) can be used to calculate correlation:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Based on the correlation value, we can describe the level of linear association (e.g., a moderately high positive relationship). However, it’s also important to visually confirm the actual association, as this helps us better understand the data. For this purpose, we can use the \(\texttt{plot()}\) function in R:

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
We can rewrite labels by using the \(\texttt{xlab}\) and \(\texttt{ylab}\) arguments.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Also, change the plotting character and colors with the \(\texttt{col}\) argument.






Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 5
text:
Defensive Capability
Unlike offensive capability, defensive capability in baseball is closely tied to the performance of pitchers. For defensive measures, smaller values indicate better performance, leading us to expect a negative association with winning percentage. For example, \(\texttt{ERA}\) (Earned Run Average) is a classic measure of a pitcher’s ability. Let’s examine the correlation and create a scatter plot to confirm this relationship.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

title: Lab 5
text:
Overall Capability
The variables ‘runs per game’ and ‘opponent runs per game’ are valid offensive and defensive metrics in baseball. Let’s examine the correlation and create scatter plots to confirm their relationship.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Now, let us want to combine these two analytics to measure the overall capability of a MLB team. The idea is very simple. By subtracting \(\texttt{ORPG}\) from \(\texttt{RPG}\), we quantify the actual “net runs per game” compared to opponent team: \[\texttt{NRPG}=\texttt{RPG}-\texttt{ORPG}.\] Please create the new variable in R, and check the correlation and display the scatter plot.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
Do you think the created \(\texttt{NRPG}\) would be a good overall performance measure?

title: Lab 5
text:
Lab Questions

Among the six variables, \(\texttt{RPG}\), \(\texttt{BA}\), \(\texttt{OPS}\), \(\texttt{ORPG}\), \(\texttt{ERA}\), and \(\texttt{WHIP}\), we wish to choose the best offensive measure and the best defensive measure, respectively. Please perform correlation analysis and provide your conclusion.



Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Note that the \(\texttt{NRPG}\) we have defined is just one way to combine \(\texttt{RPG}\) and \(\texttt{ORPG}\). We can also consider the “ratio of runs per game” by dividing \(\texttt{ORPG}\) from \(\texttt{RPG}\). Create a new variable \(\texttt{RRPG}\) for the “ratio of runs per game” and compare the result with \(\texttt{NRPG}\). Which one would be preferable to measure the overall performance of a MLB team?
